hints_html:
Simplifying the enumerator first might help. Remember the rule for the product of exponentials

\[\begin{aligned} (e^a)(e^b) = e^{a+b}.\end{aligned}\]
hints_raw: Simplifying the enumerator first might help. Remember the rule for the product of exponentials: <math>(e^a)(e^b) = e^{a+b}.</math>
question: 6 (a)
sols_html:
We first simplify using the exponential rules to get \(f(x) = e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}.\) Then we can solve for \(f(x) = 0\).

\[\begin{aligned} e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3} &= 0\\ x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3 &= \ln(0).\end{aligned}\]

By taking the natural logarithm of both sides, we get a \(\ln(0)\) on the right hand side which is bad since \(0\) is not in the domain of the natural logarithm. So we conclude that there cannot be a solution to the equation \(f(x)=0\). Hence, we have \(0\) solutions.
sols_latex:
We first simplify using the exponential rules to get
$f(x) = e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}.$ Then we can solve for $f(x) = 0$.

\begin{align*}
e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3} &= 0\\
x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3 &= \ln(0).
\end{align*}

By taking the natural logarithm of both sides, we get a $\ln(0)$ on the
right hand side which is bad since $0$ is not in the domain of the
natural logarithm. So we conclude that there cannot be a solution to the
equation $f(x)=0$. Hence, we have $0$ solutions.
sols_raw:
We first simplify using the exponential rules to get <math>f(x) = e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}.</math> Then we can solve for <math>f(x) = 0</math>.

<math>\begin{align}
e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3} &= 0\\
x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3 &= \ln(0).\end{align}</math>

By taking the natural logarithm of both sides, we get a <math>\ln(0)</math> on the right hand side which is bad since <math>0</math> is not in the domain of the natural logarithm. So we conclude that there cannot be a solution to the equation <math>f(x)=0</math>. Hence, we have <math>0</math> solutions.
statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \dfrac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}.\end{aligned}\]

(a) How many solutions are there to the equation \(f(x)=0\)? Justify your answer.
statement_raw:
Consider the function: <math>f(x) = \dfrac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}.</math>

'''(a)''' How many solutions are there to the equation <math>f(x)=0</math>? Justify your answer.
